Pattern Masking for Dictionary Matching

Panagiotis Charalampopoulos    Huiping Chen    Peter Christen    Grigorios Loukides    Nadia Pisanti    Solon P. Pissis    Jakub Radoszewski
Abstract

In the Pattern Masking for Dictionary Matching (PMDM) problem, we are given a dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of d𝑑d strings, each of length ℓℓ\ell, a query string q𝑞q of length ℓℓ\ell, and a positive integer z𝑧z, and we are asked to compute a smallest set K⊆{1,…,ℓ}𝐾1…ℓK\subseteq\{1,\ldots,\ell\}, so that if q​[i]𝑞delimited-[]𝑖q[i], for all i∈K𝑖𝐾i\in K, is replaced by a wildcard, then q𝑞q matches at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. The PMDM problem lies at the heart of two important applications featured in large-scale real-world systems: record linkage of databases that contain sensitive information, and query term dropping. In both applications, solving PMDM allows for providing data utility guarantees as opposed to existing approaches.

We first show, through a reduction from the well-known k𝑘k-Clique problem, that a decision version of the PMDM problem is NP-complete, even for strings over a binary alphabet.

A straightforward algorithm for PMDM runs in time 𝒪​(2ℓ​d)𝒪superscript2ℓ𝑑\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}d). We present a data structure for PMDM that answers queries over 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} in time 𝒪​(2ℓ/2​(2ℓ/2+τ)​ℓ)𝒪superscript2ℓ2superscript2ℓ2𝜏ℓ\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell/2}(2^{\ell/2}+\tau)\ell) and requires space 𝒪​(2ℓ​d2/τ2+2ℓ/2​d)𝒪superscript2ℓsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝜏2superscript2ℓ2𝑑\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}d^{2}/\tau^{2}+2^{\ell/2}d), for any parameter τ∈[1,d]𝜏1𝑑\tau\in[1,d]. All known indexing data structures for pattern matching with wildcards incur some exponential factor with respect to the number of allowed wildcards in the query time or space [Cole et al., STOC 2004; Bille et al., TOCS 2014; Lewenstein et al., TCS 2014]. As opposed to PMDM, in pattern matching with wildcards, the wildcard positions are fixed.

We also approach the problem from a more practical perspective. We show an 𝒪​((d​ℓ)k/3+d​ℓ)𝒪superscript𝑑ℓ𝑘3𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}((d\ell)^{k/3}+d\ell)-time and 𝒪​(d​ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell)-space algorithm for PMDM if k=|K|=𝒪​(1)𝑘𝐾𝒪1k=|K|=\mathcal{O}(1). This algorithm, executed with small k𝑘k, is the backbone of a greedy heuristic that we propose. Our experiments on real and synthetic datasets show that our heuristic finds nearly-optimal solutions in practice and is also very efficient. We generalize our exact algorithm to mask multiple query strings simultaneously.

We complement our results by showing a two-way polynomial-time reduction between PMDM and the Minimum Union problem [Chlamtáč et al., SODA 2017]. This gives a polynomial-time 𝒪​(d1/4+ϵ)𝒪superscript𝑑14italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(d^{1/4+\epsilon})-approximation algorithm for PMDM, which is tight under plausible complexity conjectures.

keywords:
string algorithms, pattern matching, dictionary matching, wildcards

\relatedversion

1 Introduction

This paper formalizes the Pattern Masking for Dictionary Matching (PMDM) problem: Given a dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of d𝑑d strings, each of length ℓℓ\ell, a query string q𝑞q of length ℓℓ\ell, and a positive integer z𝑧z, PMDM asks to compute a smallest set K⊆{1,…,ℓ}𝐾1…ℓK\subseteq\{1,\ldots,\ell\}, so that if q​[i]𝑞delimited-[]𝑖q[i], for all i∈K𝑖𝐾i\in K, is replaced by a wildcard, q𝑞q matches at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. Equivalently, PMDM asks to minimize the union K𝐾K of mismatching positions between q𝑞q and strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} to obtain at least z𝑧z matches after replacing the positions in K𝐾K with wildcards.

Let us start with a true incident to illustrate the essence of the PMDM problem. In the Netherlands, water companies bill the non-drinking and drinking water separately. The 6th author of this paper had direct debit for the former but not for the latter. When he tried to set up the direct debit for the latter, he received the following message by the company:

⬇
Is this you?
Initial: S. Name: P****s E-mail address: s******13@g***l.com
Bank account number: NL10RABO********11.

The rationale of the data masking is: the client should be able to identify themselves but not infer the identity of any other client. Thus, the masked version of the data should conceal as few symbols as possible (set K𝐾K) but correspond to a sufficient number (z𝑧z) of other clients.

In fact, the PMDM problem lies at the heart of two important applications, featured in large-scale real-world systems: (I) Record linkage of databases containing personal data [58, 42, 43, 55, 60], and (II) Query term dropping [10, 30, 45, 57].

Record linkage is the task of identifying records that refer to the same entities across databases, in situations where no entity identifiers are available in these databases [23, 33, 50]. This task is of high importance in various application domains featuring personal data, ranging from the health sector and social science research, to national statistics and crime and fraud detection [23, 38]. In a typical setting, the task is to link two databases that contain names or other attributes, known collectively as quasi-identifiers (QIDs) [59]. The similarity between each pair of records (a record from one of the databases and a record from the other) is calculated with respect to their values in QIDs, and then all compared record pairs are classified into matches (the pair is assumed to refer to the same person), non-matches (the two records in the pair are assumed to refer to different people), and potential matches (no decision about whether the pair is a match or non-match can be made) [23, 33]. Unfortunately, potential matches happen quite often [11]. A common approach [58, 55] to deal with potential matches is to conduct a manual clerical review, where a domain expert looks at the attribute values in record pairs and then makes a manual match or non-match decision. At the same time, to comply with policies and legislation, one needs to prevent domain experts from inferring the identity of the people represented in the manually assessed record pairs [55]. The challenge is to achieve desired data protection/utility guarantees; i.e., enabling a domain expert to make good decisions without inferring peoples’ identities.

To address this challenge, we can solve PMDM twice, for a potential match (q1,q2)subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2(q_{1},q_{2}). The first time we use as input the query string q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and a reference dictionary (database) 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} containing personal records from a sufficiently large population (typically, much larger than the databases to be linked). The second time, we use as input q2subscript𝑞2q_{2} instead of q1subscript𝑞1q_{1}. Since each masked q𝑞q derived by solving PMDM matches at least z𝑧z records in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, the domain expert would need to distinguish between at least z𝑧z individuals in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} to be able to infer the identity of the individual corresponding to the masked string. The underlying assumption is that 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} contains one record per individual. Also, some wildcards from one masked string can be superimposed on another to ensure that the expert does not gain more knowledge from stitching the two strings together, and the resulting strings would still match at least z𝑧z records in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. Offering such privacy is desirable in real record linkage systems where sensitive databases containing personal data are being linked [43, 60]. On the other hand, since each masked q𝑞q contains the minimum number of wildcards, the domain expert is still able to use the masked q𝑞q to meaningfully classify a record pair as a match or as a non-match. Offering such utility is again desirable in record linkage systems [55]. Record linkage is an important application for our techniques, because no existing approach can provide privacy and utility guarantees when releasing linkage results to domain experts [44]. In particular, existing approaches [43, 44] recognize the need to offer privacy by preventing the domain expert from distinguishing between a small number of individuals, but provide no algorithm for offering such privacy, let alone an algorithm offering utility guarantees as we do.

Query term dropping is an information retrieval task that seeks to drop keywords (terms) from a query, so that the remaining keywords retrieve a sufficiently large number of documents. This task is performed by search engines, such as Google [10], and by e-commerce platforms such as e-Bay [45], to improve a user’s experience [30, 57] by making sufficiently many search results available to them. We can perform query dropping by solving PMDM on a dictionary of strings corresponding to document terms, and a query string, corresponding to a user’s query. Then, we provide the user with the masked query, after removing all wildcards, and with its matching strings from the dictionary. Query term dropping is an important application for our techniques, because existing techniques [57] do not minimize the number of dropped terms. Rather, they drop keywords randomly, which may unnecessarily shorten the query, or drop keywords based on custom rules, which is not sufficiently generic to deal with all queries. More generally, our techniques can be applied to drop terms from any top-z𝑧z database query [35], to ensure there are z𝑧z results in the query answer.

Related Algorithmic Work.

Let us denote the wildcard symbol by ⋆⋆\star and provide a brief overview of works related to PMDM, the main problem considered in this paper.

  • •

    Partial Match: Given a dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of d𝑑d strings over an alphabet Σ={0,1}Σ01\Sigma=\{0,1\}, each of length ℓℓ\ell, and a string q𝑞q over Σ⊔{⋆}square-unionΣ⋆\Sigma\sqcup\{\star\} of length ℓℓ\ell, the problem asks whether q𝑞q matches any string from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. This is a well-studied problem [16, 19, 37, 49, 52, 53, 56]. Patrascu [52] showed that any data structure for the Partial Match problem with cell-probe complexity t𝑡t must use space 2Ω​(ℓ/t)superscript2Ωℓ𝑡2^{\Omega(\ell/t)}, assuming the word size is 𝒪​(d1−ϵ/t)𝒪superscript𝑑1italic-ϵ𝑡\mathcal{O}(d^{1-\epsilon}/t), for any constant ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0. The key difference to PMDM is that the wildcard positions in the query strings are fixed.

  • •

    Dictionary Matching with k𝑘k-wildcards: Given a dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of total size N𝑁N over an alphabet ΣΣ\Sigma and a query string q𝑞q of length ℓℓ\ell over Σ⊔{⋆}square-unionΣ⋆\Sigma\sqcup\{\star\} with up to k𝑘k wildcards, the problem asks for the set of matches of q𝑞q in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. This is essentially a parameterized variant of the Partial Match problem. The seminal paper of Cole, Gottlieb and Lewenstein [26] proposed a data structure occupying 𝒪​(N​logk⁡N)𝒪𝑁superscript𝑘𝑁\mathcal{O}(N\log^{k}\!N) space allowing for 𝒪​(ℓ+2k​log⁡log⁡N+|output|)𝒪ℓsuperscript2𝑘𝑁output\mathcal{O}(\ell\!+\!2^{k}\!\log\log N\!+\!|\textsf{output}|)-time querying. This data structure is based on recursively computing a heavy-light decomposition of the suffix tree and copying the subtrees hanging off light children. Generalizations and slight improvements have been proposed in [46] and [15]. In [15] the authors also proposed an alternative data structure that instead of a logk⁡Nsuperscript𝑘𝑁\log^{k}\!\!N factor in the space complexity has a multiplicative |Σ|k2superscriptΣsuperscript𝑘2|\Sigma|^{k^{2}} factor. Nearly-linear-sized data structures that essentially try all different combinations of letters in the place of wildcards and hence incur a |Σ|ksuperscriptΣ𝑘|\Sigma|^{k} factor in the query time have been proposed in [15, 47]. On the lower bound side, Afshani and Nielsen [4] showed that, in the pointer machine model, essentially any data structure for the problem in scope must have exponential dependency on k𝑘k in either the space or the query time, explaining the barriers hit by the existing approaches.

For other related works (Dictionary Matching with k𝑘k-errors [62, 17, 26, 13, 18, 14] and Enumerating Motifs with k𝑘k-wildcards [31, 8, 12, 51, 6, 54]), see Appendix A.

Our Contributions.

We consider the word-RAM model of computations with w𝑤w-bit machine words, where w=Ω​(log⁡(d​ℓ))𝑤Ω𝑑ℓw=\Omega(\log(d\ell)), for stating our results. We make the following contributions:

  1. 1.

    A reduction from the k𝑘k-Clique problem to a decision version of the PMDM problem, which implies that it is NP-complete, even for strings over a binary alphabet; see Section 3 and Appendix B for a short discussion on the hardness of the k𝑘k-Clique problem.

  2. 2.

    A polynomial-time 𝒪​(d1/4+ϵ)𝒪superscript𝑑14italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(d^{1/4+\epsilon})-approximation algorithm for PMDM, which is tight under plausible complexity conjectures; see Section 4 and Appendix C.

  3. 3.

    A data structure for PMDM that answers queries over 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} in time 𝒪​(2ℓ/2​(2ℓ/2+τ)​ℓ)𝒪superscript2ℓ2superscript2ℓ2𝜏ℓ\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell/2}(2^{\ell/2}+\tau)\ell) and requires space 𝒪​(2ℓ​d2/τ2+2ℓ/2​d)𝒪superscript2ℓsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝜏2superscript2ℓ2𝑑\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}d^{2}/\tau^{2}+2^{\ell/2}d), for any parameter τ∈[1,d]𝜏1𝑑\tau\in[1,d]; see Section 5.

  4. 4.

    An 𝒪​((d​ℓ)k/3+d​ℓ)𝒪superscript𝑑ℓ𝑘3𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}((d\ell)^{k/3}+d\ell)-time and 𝒪​(d​ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell)-space algorithm for PMDM for k=𝒪​(1)𝑘𝒪1k=\mathcal{O}(1); see Section 6.

  5. 5.

    We consider the generalized version of PMDM, referred to as MPMDM: we are given a collection ℳℳ\mathcal{M} of m𝑚m query strings (instead of one query string) and we are asked to compute a smallest set K𝐾K so that, for every q𝑞q from ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, if q​[i]𝑞delimited-[]𝑖q[i], for all i∈K𝑖𝐾i\in K, is replaced by a wildcard, then q𝑞q matches at least z𝑧z strings from dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. We show an 𝒪​((d​ℓ)k/3​zm−1+d​ℓ)𝒪superscript𝑑ℓ𝑘3superscript𝑧𝑚1𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}((d\ell)^{k/3}z^{m-1}+d\ell)-time algorithm for MPMDM for k=𝒪​(1)𝑘𝒪1k=\mathcal{O}(1) and m=𝒪​(1)𝑚𝒪1m=\mathcal{O}(1); see Section 7.

  6. 6.

    A greedy heuristic based on the 𝒪​((d​ℓ)k/3+d​ℓ)𝒪superscript𝑑ℓ𝑘3𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}((d\ell)^{k/3}+d\ell)-time algorithm; see Section 8 and Appendix D.

  7. 7.

    Experiments using real-world and synthetic data showing that our heuristic finds nearly-optimal solutions in practice and is also very efficient; see Section 8 and Appendix E.

2 Definitions and Notation

An alphabet ΣΣ\Sigma is a finite nonempty set whose elements are called letters. Let x=x​[1]​⋯​x​[n]𝑥𝑥delimited-[]1⋯𝑥delimited-[]𝑛x=x[1]\cdots x[n] be a string of length |x|=n𝑥𝑛|x|=n over ΣΣ\Sigma. For two indices 1≤i≤j≤n1𝑖𝑗𝑛1\leq i\leq j\leq n, x​[i​..​j]=x​[i]​⋯​x​[j]x[i\mathinner{.\,.}j]=x[i]\cdots x[j] is the substring of x𝑥x that starts at position i𝑖i and ends at position j𝑗j of x𝑥x. By ε𝜀\varepsilon we denote the empty string of length 00. A prefix of x𝑥x is a substring of x𝑥x of the form x​[1​..​j]x[1\mathinner{.\,.}j], and a suffix of x𝑥x is a substring of x𝑥x of the form x​[i​..​n]x[i\mathinner{.\,.}n]. A dictionary is a collection of strings. We also consider alphabet Σ⋆=Σ⊔{⋆}subscriptΣ⋆square-unionΣ⋆\Sigma_{\star}=\Sigma\sqcup\{\star\}, where ⋆⋆\star is a wildcard letter that is not in ΣΣ\Sigma and matches all letters from Σ⋆subscriptΣ⋆\Sigma_{\star}. Then, given a string x𝑥x over Σ⋆subscriptΣ⋆\Sigma_{\star} and a string y𝑦y over ΣΣ\Sigma with |x|=|y|𝑥𝑦|x|=|y|, we say that x𝑥x matches y𝑦y if and only if x​[i]=y​[i]​ or ​x​[i]=⋆, for all ​1≤i≤|x|formulae-sequence𝑥delimited-[]𝑖𝑦delimited-[]𝑖 or 𝑥delimited-[]𝑖⋆ for all 1𝑖𝑥x[i]=y[i]\mbox{\ or\ }x[i]=\star,\mbox{\ for all\ }1\leq i\leq|x|. Given a string x𝑥x of length n𝑛n and a set S⊆{1,…,n}𝑆1…𝑛S\subseteq\{1,\ldots,n\}, we denote by xS=x⊗Ssubscript𝑥𝑆tensor-product𝑥𝑆x_{S}=x\otimes S the string obtained by first setting xS=xsubscript𝑥𝑆𝑥x_{S}=x and then xS​[i]=⋆subscript𝑥𝑆delimited-[]𝑖⋆x_{S}[i]=\star, for all i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S. We then say that x𝑥x is masked by S𝑆S.

The main problem considered in this paper is the following.

Pattern Masking for Dictionary Matching (PMDM)
Input: A dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of d𝑑d strings, each of length ℓℓ\ell, a string q𝑞q of length ℓℓ\ell, and a positive integer z𝑧z. Output: A smallest set K⊆{1,…,ℓ}𝐾1…ℓK\subseteq\{1,\ldots,\ell\} such that qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K matches at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}.

We refer to the problem of computing only the size k𝑘k of a smallest set K𝐾K as PMDM-Size. We also consider the data structure variant of the PMDM problem in which 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is given to us for preprocessing and q,z𝑞𝑧q,z queries are to be answered on-line. Throughout, we assume that k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1 as the case k=0𝑘0k=0 corresponds to the well-studied dictionary matching problem for which there exists a classic optimal solution [5]. We further assume z≤d𝑧𝑑z\leq d; otherwise the PMDM has trivially no solution. In what follows, we use N𝑁N to denote d​ℓ𝑑ℓd\ell.

3 PMDM-Size is NP-complete

We show that the decision version of PMDM-Size is NP-complete.

k𝑘k-PMDM
Input: A dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of d𝑑d strings, each of length ℓℓ\ell, a string q𝑞q of length ℓℓ\ell, and positive integers z≤d𝑧𝑑z\leq d and k≤ℓ𝑘ℓk\leq\ell. Output: Is there a set K⊆{1,…,ℓ}𝐾1…ℓK\subseteq\{1,\ldots,\ell\} of size k𝑘k, such that qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K matches at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}?

A clique is a subset of the nodes of an undirected graph that are pairwise adjacent. Our reduction is from the well-known NP-complete k𝑘k-Clique problem [39]: Given an undirected graph G𝐺G on n𝑛n nodes and a positive integer k𝑘k, decide whether G𝐺G contains a clique of size k𝑘k.

Theorem 3.1.

k𝑘k-PMDM is NP-complete for strings over a binary alphabet.

Proof 3.2.

Let G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) be an undirected graph on n=|V|𝑛𝑉n=|V| nodes numbered 111 through n𝑛n, in which we are looking for a clique of size k𝑘k. We reduce k𝑘k-Clique to k𝑘k-PMDM as follows. Consider alphabet {a,b}ab\{\texttt{a},\texttt{b}\}. Set q=an𝑞superscripta𝑛q=\texttt{a}^{n}, and for every edge (u,v)∈E𝑢𝑣𝐸(u,v)\in E such that u<v𝑢𝑣u<v, add string au−1​bav−u−1​ban−vsuperscripta𝑢1superscriptba𝑣𝑢1superscriptba𝑛𝑣\texttt{a}^{u-1}\texttt{b}\texttt{a}^{v-u-1}\texttt{b}\texttt{a}^{n-v} to 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. Set z=k​(k−1)/2𝑧𝑘𝑘12z=k(k-1)/2. Then G𝐺G contains a clique of size k𝑘k, if and only if k𝑘k-PMDM returns a positive answer. k𝑘k-PMDM is in NP and the result follows.

An example of the reduction from k𝑘k-Clique to k𝑘k-PMDM is shown in Figure 1. Our reduction shows that solving k𝑘k-PMDM efficiently even for strings over a binary alphabet would imply a breakthrough for the k𝑘k-Clique problem (see Appendix B for more details).

Any algorithm solving PMDM-Size can be trivially applied to solve k𝑘k-PMDM.

Theorem 3.3.

PMDM-Size is NP-hard for strings over a binary alphabet.

4 Approximation Algorithm for PMDM

Clearly, PMDM is at least as hard as PMDM-Size because it also outputs the positions of the wildcards (set K𝐾K). Thus, PMDM is also NP-hard. We show existence of a polynomial-time approximation algorithm for PMDM whose approximation factor is given with respect to d𝑑d. The authors of [22] show a polynomial-time 𝒪​(d1/4+ϵ)𝒪superscript𝑑14italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(d^{1/4+\epsilon})-approximation algorithm, for any constant ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, for the Minimum Union (MU) problem. In Appendix C, we show a polynomial-time reduction from PMDM to MU that implies the following result.

Theorem 4.1.

For any constant ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, there is a polynomial-time 𝒪​(d1/4+ϵ)𝒪superscript𝑑14italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(d^{1/4+\epsilon})-approximation algorithm for PMDM.

In addition, the authors of [22] show that their 𝒪​(d1/4+ϵ)𝒪superscript𝑑14italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(d^{1/4+\epsilon})-approximation algorithm for MU is tight under plausible complexity conjectures. In Appendix C, we also show that approximating the MU problem can be reduced to approximating PMDM in polynomial time and hence the same tightness results apply to PMDM.

Applying Theorem 4.1 to solve PMDM is not practical, as in real-world applications, such as those in Introduction, d𝑑d is typically in the order of thousands or millions [24, 28, 30, 57].

5 A Data Structure for PMDM Queries

We next show algorithms and data structures for the PMDM problem under the assumption that 2ℓsuperscript2ℓ2^{\ell} is reasonably small. Specifically, we consider the word-RAM model with w𝑤w-bit machine words, where w=Ω​(log⁡N+ℓ)𝑤Ω𝑁ℓw\!=\!\Omega(\log\!N+\ell). We measure space in terms of w𝑤w-bit machine words and focus on showing space vs. query-time trade-offs for answering q,z𝑞𝑧q,z PMDM queries over 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. A summary of the complexities of the data structures is shown in Table 1. Specifically, algorithm Small-ℓℓ\ell and data structure Simple are used as building blocks in the more involved data structure Split, shown in the following theorem.

Theorem 5.1.

There exists a data structure that answers q,z𝑞𝑧q,z PMDM queries over 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} in time 𝒪​(2ℓ/2​(2ℓ/2+τ)​ℓ)𝒪superscript2ℓ2superscript2ℓ2𝜏ℓ\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell/2}(2^{\ell/2}+\tau)\ell) and requires space 𝒪​(2ℓ​d2/τ2+2ℓ/2​d)𝒪superscript2ℓsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝜏2superscript2ℓ2𝑑\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}d^{2}/\tau^{2}+2^{\ell/2}d), for any parameter τ∈[1,d]𝜏1𝑑\tau\in[1,d].

Algorithm Small-ℓℓ\ell: 𝒪​(d​ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell) Space, 𝒪​(2ℓ​ℓ+d​ℓ)𝒪superscript2ℓℓ𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}\ell+d\ell) Query Time.

No data structure on top of the dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is stored. In the query algorithm, we initialize an array A𝐴A of size 2ℓsuperscript2ℓ2^{\ell} with zeros. For every possible ℓℓ\ell-bit vector i𝑖i, representing Ki⊆{1,…,ℓ}subscript𝐾𝑖1…ℓK_{i}\subseteq\{1,\ldots,\ell\}, A​[i]𝐴delimited-[]𝑖A[i] will finally store the number of strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that match qKi=q⊗Kisubscript𝑞subscript𝐾𝑖tensor-product𝑞subscript𝐾𝑖q_{K_{i}}=q\otimes K_{i}. For every string s∈𝒟𝑠𝒟s\in\mathcal{D}, we compute the set of positions in which s𝑠s and q𝑞q differ, and for this Kisubscript𝐾𝑖K_{i}, we increment A​[i]𝐴delimited-[]𝑖A[i]. This computation takes 𝒪​(d​ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell) time and 𝒪​(1)𝒪1\mathcal{O}(1) extra space. Then we apply a folklore dynamic-programming-based approach (cf. [2]) to count the number of strings matching qKisubscript𝑞subscript𝐾𝑖q_{K_{i}}. This takes 𝒪​(ℓ​2ℓ)𝒪ℓsuperscript2ℓ\mathcal{O}(\ell 2^{\ell}) time and 𝒪​(2ℓ)𝒪superscript2ℓ\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}) extra space. Thus, overall, the (query) time required by algorithm Small-ℓℓ\ell is 𝒪​(ℓ​2ℓ+d​ℓ)𝒪ℓsuperscript2ℓ𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(\ell 2^{\ell}\!+\!d\ell) and the space is 𝒪​(2ℓ+d​ℓ)𝒪superscript2ℓ𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}\!+\!d\ell).

Let us denote by z0∈[1,d]subscript𝑧01𝑑z_{0}\!\in\![1,d] the smallest z𝑧z value for which we support PMDM queries. We first present Simple, an auxiliary data structure, which we will apply later on to construct Split, a data structure with the space/query-time trade-off given by Theorem 5.1.

DS Simple: 𝒪​((ℓk)⋅d/z0)𝒪⋅FRACOPℓ𝑘𝑑subscript𝑧0\mathcal{O}(\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{1}{\ell}{k}\cdot d/z_{0}) Space, 𝒪​((ℓk))𝒪FRACOPℓ𝑘\mathcal{O}(\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{1}{\ell}{k}) Query Time, for Fixed k𝑘k.

For each possible subset of {1,…,ℓ}1…ℓ\{1,\ldots,\ell\} of size k𝑘k, we mask the k𝑘k corresponding positions in all strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. We sort the masked strings lexicographically in order to have counts for each distinct (masked) string and construct a dictionary (hash map): the key is the fingerprint of a masked string (item) and the value is its count. The space occupied by the dictionary is 𝒪​((ℓk)⋅d/z0)𝒪⋅FRACOPℓ𝑘𝑑subscript𝑧0\mathcal{O}(\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{1}{\ell}{k}\cdot d/z_{0}) by storing only the items (fingerprints of masked strings) whose count is at least z0subscript𝑧0z_{0}. Upon an on-line query q𝑞q of length ℓℓ\ell with z≥z0𝑧subscript𝑧0z\geq z_{0}, we attempt all possible masks of size k𝑘k for q𝑞q and read the count from the dictionary. All possible (ℓk)FRACOPℓ𝑘\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{1}{\ell}{k} fingerprints can be computed in time 𝒪​((ℓk))𝒪FRACOPℓ𝑘\mathcal{O}(\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{1}{\ell}{k}) if we use a folklore algorithm for generating the combinations (cf. [9]) and a rolling hash function for the fingerprints, such as the classic Karp-Rabin (KR) fingerprints [40].

Note that (ℓk)FRACOPℓ𝑘\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{1}{\ell}{k} can be asymptotically as large as 2ℓ/ℓsuperscript2ℓℓ2^{\ell}/\sqrt{\ell}, e.g. for ℓ=2​kℓ2𝑘\ell=2k. When 2ℓ=o​(d)superscript2ℓ𝑜𝑑2^{\ell}=o(d), we manage to decrease the exponential dependency on ℓℓ\ell in the space complexity, incurring extra time in the query. To this end, we next present the Split data structure.

DS Split: 𝒪​(2ℓ​d2/τ2+2ℓ/2​d/z0)𝒪superscript2ℓsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝜏2superscript2ℓ2𝑑subscript𝑧0\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}d^{2}/\tau^{2}+2^{\ell/2}d/z_{0}) Space, 𝒪​(2ℓ/2⋅(2ℓ/2+τ)​ℓ)𝒪⋅superscript2ℓ2superscript2ℓ2𝜏ℓ\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell/2}\cdot(2^{\ell/2}+\tau)\ell) Query Time, for any τ𝜏\tau.

This trade-off only makes sense for τ=ω​(d)𝜏𝜔𝑑\tau=\omega(\sqrt{d}); otherwise the Simple data structure is better.

We split each string p∈𝒟𝑝𝒟p\in\mathcal{D} roughly in the middle, to prefix pLsubscript𝑝𝐿p_{L} and suffix pRsubscript𝑝𝑅p_{R}; specifically, p=pL​pR𝑝subscript𝑝𝐿subscript𝑝𝑅p=p_{L}p_{R} and |pL|=⌈ℓ/2⌉subscript𝑝𝐿ℓ2|p_{L}|=\lceil\ell/2\rceil. We create dictionaries 𝒟L={pL:p∈𝒟}subscript𝒟𝐿conditional-setsubscript𝑝𝐿𝑝𝒟\mathcal{D}_{L}\!=\!\{p_{L}\!:\!p\!\in\!\mathcal{D}\} and 𝒟R={pR:p∈𝒟}subscript𝒟𝑅conditional-setsubscript𝑝𝑅𝑝𝒟\mathcal{D}_{R}\!=\!\{p_{R}\!:\!p\!\in\!\mathcal{D}\}. Let us now explain how to process 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L}; we process 𝒟Rsubscript𝒟𝑅\mathcal{D}_{R} analogously. Let λ=⌈ℓ/2⌉𝜆ℓ2\lambda\!=\!\lceil\ell/2\rceil. For each subset of {1,…,λ}1…𝜆\{1,\ldots,\lambda\}, we construct DS Simple over 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L}. This requires space 𝒪​(2ℓ/2​d/z0)𝒪superscript2ℓ2𝑑subscript𝑧0\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell/2}d/z_{0}). Let τ𝜏\tau be an input parameter, intuitively used as the minimum frequency threshold. For each of the possible 2λsuperscript2𝜆2^{\lambda} masks, we can have at most ⌊d/τ⌋𝑑𝜏\lfloor d/\tau\rfloor (masked) strings with frequency at least τ𝜏\tau. Over all masks, we thus have at most 2λ⋅⌊d/τ⌋⋅superscript2𝜆𝑑𝜏2^{\lambda}\cdot\lfloor d/\tau\rfloor such strings; we call them τ𝜏\tau-frequent. For every pair of τ𝜏\tau-frequent strings, one from 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} and one from 𝒟Rsubscript𝒟𝑅\mathcal{D}_{R}, we store the number of occurrences of their concatenation in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. This requires space 𝒪​(2ℓ​d2/τ2)𝒪superscript2ℓsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝜏2\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}d^{2}/\tau^{2}).

Consider 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L}. For each mask i𝑖i and each string pL∈𝒟Lsubscript𝑝𝐿subscript𝒟𝐿p_{L}\in\mathcal{D}_{L}, we can afford to store the list of all strings in 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} that match pL⊗itensor-productsubscript𝑝𝐿𝑖p_{L}\otimes i. Note that we have computed this information when sorting for constructing the Simple data structure over 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L}. This information requires space 𝒪​(2ℓ/2​d/z0)𝒪superscript2ℓ2𝑑subscript𝑧0\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell/2}d/z_{0}). Thus, Split requires 𝒪​(2ℓ​d2/τ2+2ℓ/2​d/z0)𝒪superscript2ℓsuperscript𝑑2superscript𝜏2superscript2ℓ2𝑑subscript𝑧0\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell}d^{2}/\tau^{2}+2^{\ell/2}d/z_{0}) space overall.

Let us now show how to answer an on-line q,z𝑞𝑧q,z query. We iterate over all possible 2ℓsuperscript2ℓ2^{\ell} masks performing exact computations and thus we can answer the query q𝑞q for any given z𝑧z. Given mask i𝑖i we split q′=q⊗isuperscript𝑞′tensor-product𝑞𝑖q^{\prime}=q\otimes i into two halves, qL′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿q^{\prime}_{L} and qR′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝑅q^{\prime}_{R} with q′=qL′​qR′superscript𝑞′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝑅q^{\prime}=q^{\prime}_{L}q^{\prime}_{R} and |qL′|=⌈ℓ/2⌉subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿ℓ2|q^{\prime}_{L}|=\lceil\ell/2\rceil.

The intuition is that, if both halves are τ𝜏\tau-frequent, we have precomputed the frequency of their concatenation as explained above. If (at least) one of the two halves is τ𝜏\tau-infrequent we have to resort to the Small-ℓℓ\ell algorithm to count exactly the frequency of q𝑞q using the list information enhancing the Simple data structure.

We distinguish among two cases: (i) one of the two halves is τ𝜏\tau-infrequent; or (ii) both halves are τ𝜏\tau-frequent. We first check if qL′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿q^{\prime}_{L} is τ𝜏\tau-infrequent using the data structure Simple we have constructed for 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L}. If so, we apply algorithm Small-ℓℓ\ell on the following input: (i) the second half qR′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝑅q^{\prime}_{R} and (ii) a dictionary consisting of at most τ𝜏\tau strings from 𝒟Rsubscript𝒟𝑅\mathcal{D}_{R} that correspond to the right halves of strings in 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} that match qL′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿q^{\prime}_{L}. (Recall that the list of matches for qL′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿q^{\prime}_{L} is stored by our DS.) We proceed symmetrically if qL′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿q^{\prime}_{L} is τ𝜏\tau-frequent and qR′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝑅q^{\prime}_{R} is τ𝜏\tau-infrequent. Finally, if both qL′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝐿q^{\prime}_{L} and qR′subscriptsuperscript𝑞′𝑅q^{\prime}_{R} are τ𝜏\tau-frequent we read the corresponding precomputed counter from the hash map. In any of the two cases, if the frequency of q′superscript𝑞′q^{\prime} is at least z𝑧z, we return a positive answer. We obtain Theorem 5.1 by setting z0=1subscript𝑧01z_{0}=1.

We show, for completeness, how the Split data structure can be constructed in 𝒪​(d​2ℓ)𝒪𝑑superscript2ℓ\mathcal{O}(d2^{\ell}) time. The Simple data structures for 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} and DRsubscript𝐷𝑅D_{R} can be constructed in 𝒪​(2ℓ/2​d)𝒪superscript2ℓ2𝑑\mathcal{O}(2^{\ell/2}d) time. We then create a hashmap for pairs of τ𝜏\tau-frequent strings. For each of the 2ℓsuperscript2ℓ2^{\ell} possible masks, say i𝑖i, and each string p∈𝒟𝑝𝒟p\in\mathcal{D}, we split p′=p⊗isuperscript𝑝′tensor-product𝑝𝑖p^{\prime}=p\otimes i in the middle to obtain pL′subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝐿p^{\prime}_{L} and pR′subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑅p^{\prime}_{R}. If both pL′subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝐿p^{\prime}_{L} and pR′subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑅p^{\prime}_{R} are τ𝜏\tau-frequent we increment a counter associated with (pL′,pR′)subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝐿subscriptsuperscript𝑝′𝑅(p^{\prime}_{L},p^{\prime}_{R}). Again, by using a folklore algorithm for generating the 2ℓsuperscript2ℓ2^{\ell} combinations and a rolling hash function for representing strings as KR fingerprints, we obtain a total construction time of 𝒪​(d​2ℓ)𝒪𝑑superscript2ℓ\mathcal{O}(d2^{\ell}).

Comparison of the Data Structures.

Data structure Simple has lower query time than algorithm Small-ℓℓ\ell. However, its space complexity can be much higher. Data structure Split can be viewed as an intermediate option. For τ𝜏\tau as in Table 1, it has better query time than algorithm Small-ℓℓ\ell for d=ω​(23​ℓ/2)𝑑𝜔superscript23ℓ2d=\omega(2^{3\ell/2}), while keeping moderate space complexity. It always has worse query time than data structure Small, but its space complexity is lower by a factor of 2ℓ/2superscript2ℓ22^{\ell/2}. For example, for d=22​ℓ𝑑superscript22ℓd=2^{2\ell} we get the complexities shown in Table 2.

6 Exact Algorithms for a Bounded Number k𝑘k of Wildcards

We consider the following problem, which we solve by exact algorithms. These algorithms will form the backbone of our effective and efficient heuristic for the PMDM problem.

Heaviest k𝑘k-PMDM
Input: A dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of d𝑑d strings, each of length ℓℓ\ell, a string q𝑞q of length ℓℓ\ell, and a positive integer k≤d𝑘𝑑k\leq d. Output: A set K⊆{1,…,ℓ}𝐾1…ℓK\subseteq\{1,\ldots,\ell\} of size k𝑘k such that qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K matches the maximum number of strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}.

We will show the following result, which we will employ to solve the PMDM problem.

Theorem 6.1.

Heaviest k𝑘k-PMDM for k=𝒪​(1)𝑘𝒪1k\!=\!\mathcal{O}(1) can be solved in 𝒪​(N+min⁡{Nk/3,ℓk})𝒪𝑁superscript𝑁𝑘3superscriptℓ𝑘\mathcal{O}(N\!+\!\min\{N^{k/3},\ell^{k}\}) time.

A hypergraph H𝐻H is a pair (V,E)𝑉𝐸(V,E), where V𝑉V is the set of nodes of H𝐻H and E𝐸E is a set of non-empty subsets of V𝑉V, called hyperedges – in order to simplify terminology we will simply call them edges. Hypergraphs are a generalization of graphs in the sense that an edge can connect multiple nodes. Recall that the size of an edge is the number of nodes it contains. The rank of H𝐻H, denoted by r​(H)𝑟𝐻r(H), is the maximum size of an edge of H𝐻H.

We refer to a hypergraph H×K=(K,{e:e∈E,e⊆K})𝐻𝐾𝐾conditional-set𝑒formulae-sequence𝑒𝐸𝑒𝐾H\times K=(K,\{e:e\in E,e\subseteq K\}), where K𝐾K is a subset of V𝑉V, as a |K|𝐾|K|-section. H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K is the hypergraph induced by H𝐻H on the nodes of K𝐾K, and it contains all edges of H𝐻H whose elements are all in K𝐾K. A hypergraph is weighted when each of its edges is associated with a weight. We define the weight of a weighted hypergraph as the sum of the weights of all of its edges. In what follows, we also refer to weights of nodes for conceptual clarity; this is equivalent to having a singleton edge of equal weight consisting of that node.

We define the following auxiliary problem on hypergraphs (see also [21]).

Heaviest k𝑘k-Section
Input: A weighted hypergraph H=(V,E)𝐻𝑉𝐸H=(V,E) and a positive integer k𝑘k. Output: A subset K𝐾K of size k𝑘k of V𝑉V such that H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K has maximum weight.

A polynomial-time 𝒪​(n0.697831+ϵ)𝒪superscript𝑛0.697831italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(n^{0.697831+\epsilon})-approximation for Heaviest k𝑘k-Section, for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, for the case when all hyperedges of H𝐻H have size at most 3 was shown in [21] (see also [7]).

Two remarks are in place. First, we can focus on edges of size up to k𝑘k as larger edges cannot, by definition, exist in any k𝑘k-section. Second, Heaviest k𝑘k-Section is a generalization of the problem of deciding whether a (c,k)𝑐𝑘(c,k)-hyperclique (i.e., a set of k𝑘k nodes whose subsets of size c𝑐c are all in E𝐸E) exists in a graph, which in turn is a generalization of k𝑘k-Clique. Unlike k𝑘k-Clique, the (c,k)𝑐𝑘(c,k)-hyperclique problem is not known to benefit from fast matrix multiplication in general; see [48] for a discussion on its hardness.

Lemma 6.2.

Heaviest k𝑘k-PMDM can be reduced to Heaviest k𝑘k-Section for a hypergraph with ℓℓ\ell nodes and d𝑑d edges in 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N) time.

Proof 6.3.

We first compute the set Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s} of positions of mismatches of q𝑞q with each string s∈𝒟𝑠𝒟s\in\mathcal{D}. We ignore strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that match q𝑞q exactly, as they will match q𝑞q after changing any set of letters of q𝑞q to wildcards. This requires 𝒪​(d​ℓ)=𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑑ℓ𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(d\ell)=\mathcal{O}(N) time in total.

Let us consider an empty hypergraph (i.e. with no edges) H𝐻H on ℓℓ\ell nodes, numbered 111 through ℓℓ\ell. Then, for each string s∈𝒟𝑠𝒟s\in\mathcal{D}, we add Mssubscript𝑀𝑠M_{s} to the edge-set of H𝐻H if |Ms|≤ksubscript𝑀𝑠𝑘|M_{s}|\leq k; if this edge already exists, we simply increment its weight by 111.

We set the parameter k𝑘k of Heaviest k𝑘k-Section to the parameter k𝑘k of Heaviest k𝑘k-PMDM. We now observe that for K⊆V𝐾𝑉K\subseteq V with |K|=k𝐾𝑘|K|=k, the weight of H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K is equal to the number of strings that would match q𝑞q after replacing with wildcards the k𝑘k letters of q𝑞q at the positions corresponding to elements of K𝐾K. The statement follows.

An example of the reduction from Heaviest k𝑘k-Section to Heaviest k𝑘k-PMDM is shown in Figure 2.

The next lemma gives a straightforward solution to Heaviest k𝑘k-Section. It is analogous to algorithm Small-ℓℓ\ell from Section 5, but without the optimization in computing sums of weights over subsets. It implies a linear-time algorithm for Heaviest 111-Section.

Lemma 6.4.

Heaviest k𝑘k-Section can be solved in 𝒪​((2​|V|)k+|E|)𝒪superscript2𝑉𝑘𝐸\mathcal{O}((2|V|)^{k}+|E|) time and 𝒪​(|V|+|E|)𝒪𝑉𝐸\mathcal{O}(|V|+|E|) space.

Proof 6.5.

Let us store a perfect hash map that maps every edge of E𝐸E to its weight (or 0 if the edge does not exist) [29]. This takes 𝒪​(|E|)𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}(|E|) time. For every subset K⊆V𝐾𝑉K\subseteq V of size at most k𝑘k, we sum the weights of all edges corresponding to its subsets. There are (|V|k)=𝒪​(|V|k)𝐹𝑅𝐴𝐶𝑂𝑃𝑉𝑘𝒪superscript𝑉𝑘\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{1}{|V|}{k}=\mathcal{O}(|V|^{k}) choices for |K|𝐾|K|, each having 2k−1superscript2𝑘12^{k}-1 non-empty subsets. The stated time complexity follows.

We next show that for the cases k=2𝑘2k=2 and k=3𝑘3k=3, there exist more efficient solutions. In particular, we provide a linear-time algorithm for Heaviest 222-Section.

Lemma 6.6.

Heaviest 222-Section can be solved in 𝒪​(|V|+|E|)𝒪𝑉𝐸\mathcal{O}(|V|+|E|) time.

Proof 6.7.

Let K𝐾K be a set of nodes of size 222 such that H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K has maximum weight. We decompose the problem in two cases. For each of the cases, we give an algorithm that considers several 222-sections such that the heaviest of them has weight equal to that of H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K.

Case 1. There is an edge e=K𝑒𝐾e=K. For each edge e∈E𝑒𝐸e\in E of size 222, i.e. edge in the classical sense, we compute the sum of its weight and the weights of the nodes that it is incident to. This step requires 𝒪​(|E|)𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}(|E|) time.

Case 2. There is no edge equal to K𝐾K in E𝐸E. We compute H×{v1,v2}𝐻subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2H\times\{v_{1},v_{2}\}, where v1,v2subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2v_{1},v_{2} are the two nodes with maximum weight, i.e. max and second-max. This step takes 𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|) time.

In the end, we return the heaviest 222-section among those returned by the algorithms for the two cases, breaking ties arbitrarily.

We next show that for k=3𝑘3k=3 the result of Lemma 6.4 can be improved when |E|=o​(|V|2)𝐸𝑜superscript𝑉2|E|=o(|V|^{2}).

Lemma 6.8.

Heaviest 333-Section can be solved in 𝒪​(|V|⋅|E|)𝒪⋅𝑉𝐸\mathcal{O}(|V|\cdot|E|) time and 𝒪​(|V|+|E|)𝒪𝑉𝐸\mathcal{O}(|V|+|E|) space.

Proof 6.9.

Let K𝐾K be a set of nodes of size 333 such that H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K has maximum weight. We decompose the problem in the following three cases.

Case 1. There is an edge e=K𝑒𝐾e=K. We go through each edge e∈E𝑒𝐸e\in E of size 333 and compute the weight of H×e𝐻𝑒H\times e in 𝒪​(1)𝒪1\mathcal{O}(1) time. (We store the edges of H𝐻H in a perfect hash map [29].) This takes 𝒪​(|E|)𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}(|E|) time in total. Let the edge yielding the maximum weight be emaxsubscript𝑒e_{\max}.

Case 2. There is no edge of size larger than one in H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K. We compute H×{v1,v2,v3}𝐻subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2subscript𝑣3H\times\{v_{1},v_{2},v_{3}\}, where v1,v2,v3subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2subscript𝑣3v_{1},v_{2},v_{3} are the three nodes with maximum weight, i.e. max, second-max and third-max. This step takes 𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|) time.

Case 3. There is an edge of size 222 in H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K. We can pick an edge e𝑒e of size 222 from E𝐸E in 𝒪​(|E|)𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}(|E|) ways and a node v𝑣v from V𝑉V in 𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|) ways. We compute the weight of H×(e∪{v})𝐻𝑒𝑣H\times(e\cup\{v\}) for all such pairs. Let the pair yielding maximum weight be (e′,u′)superscript𝑒′superscript𝑢′(e^{\prime},u^{\prime}).

Finally, the maximum weight of H×K′𝐻superscript𝐾′H\times K^{\prime} for K′∈{emax,{v1,v2,v3},e′∪{u′}}superscript𝐾′subscript𝑒subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2subscript𝑣3superscript𝑒′superscript𝑢′K^{\prime}\in\{\,e_{\max},\,\{v_{1},v_{2},v_{3}\},\,e^{\prime}\cup\{u^{\prime}\}\,\} is equal to the weight of H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K, breaking ties arbitrarily.

Lemma 6.10.

Heaviest k𝑘k-Section for an arbitrarily large constant k≥4𝑘4k\geq 4 can be solved in 𝒪​((|V|⋅|E|)k/3)𝒪superscript⋅𝑉𝐸𝑘3\mathcal{O}((|V|\cdot|E|)^{k/3}) time and 𝒪​(|V|+|E|)𝒪𝑉𝐸\mathcal{O}(|V|+|E|) space.

Proof 6.11.

If |E|>|V|2𝐸superscript𝑉2|E|>|V|^{2}, then the simple algorithm of Lemma 6.4 solves the problem in time

𝒪​((2​|V|)k+|E|)=𝒪​(|V|k/3​(|V|2)k/3+|E|)=𝒪​((|V|⋅|E|)k/3)𝒪superscript2𝑉𝑘𝐸𝒪superscript𝑉𝑘3superscriptsuperscript𝑉2𝑘3𝐸𝒪superscript⋅𝑉𝐸𝑘3\mathcal{O}((2|V|)^{k}+|E|)=\mathcal{O}(|V|^{k/3}(|V|^{2})^{k/3}+|E|)=\mathcal{O}((|V|\cdot|E|)^{k/3})

and linear space. We can thus henceforth assume that |E|≤|V|2𝐸superscript𝑉2|E|\leq|V|^{2}.

Let K𝐾K be a set of nodes of size at most k𝑘k such that H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K has maximum weight. If H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K contains isolated nodes (i.e., nodes not contained in any edge), they can be safely deleted without altering the result. We can thus assume that H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K does not contain isolated nodes, and that |V|≤k​|E|𝑉𝑘𝐸|V|\leq k|E| since otherwise the hypergraph H𝐻H would contain isolated nodes.

We first consider the case that r​(H×K)>1𝑟𝐻𝐾1r(H\times K)>1, i.e., there is an edge of H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K of size at least 2. We design a branching algorithm that constructs several candidate sets; the ones with maximum weight will have weight equal to that of H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K. We start with set X:=∅assign𝑋X:=\emptyset. For each set X𝑋X that we process, let ZXsubscript𝑍𝑋Z_{X} be the superset of X𝑋X of size at most k𝑘k such that H×ZX𝐻subscript𝑍𝑋H\times Z_{X} has maximum weight. We have the following two cases:

Case 1. There is an edge e𝑒e in H×ZX𝐻subscript𝑍𝑋H\times Z_{X} that contains at least two nodes from ZX∖Xsubscript𝑍𝑋𝑋Z_{X}\setminus X. To account for this case, we select every possible such edge e𝑒e, set X:=X∪eassign𝑋𝑋𝑒X:=X\cup e, and continue the branching algorithm.

Case 2. Each edge in H×ZX𝐻subscript𝑍𝑋H\times Z_{X} contains at most one node from ZX∖Xsubscript𝑍𝑋𝑋Z_{X}\setminus X. In this case we conclude the branching algorithm as follows. We use a hash map of all the edges. For every node v∈V∖X𝑣𝑉𝑋v\in V\setminus X we compute its weight as the total weight of edges Y∪{v}∈E𝑌𝑣𝐸Y\cup\{v\}\in E for Y⊆X𝑌𝑋Y\subseteq X, using the hash map in 𝒪​(2k)=𝒪​(1)𝒪superscript2𝑘𝒪1\mathcal{O}(2^{k})=\mathcal{O}(1) time. Finally, in 𝒪​(|V|​k)=𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉𝑘𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|k)=\mathcal{O}(|V|) time we select k−|X|𝑘𝑋k-|X| nodes with largest weights and insert them into X𝑋X. The total time complexity of this step is 𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|). This case also works if |X|=k𝑋𝑘|X|=k and then its time complexity is only 𝒪​(1)𝒪1\mathcal{O}(1).

The correctness of this branching algorithm follows from an easy induction, showing that at every level of the branching tree there is a subset of K𝐾K.

Let us now analyze the time complexity of this branching algorithm. Each branching in Case 1 takes 𝒪​(|E|)𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}(|E|) time and increases the size of |X|𝑋|X| by at least 2. At every node of the branching tree we call the procedure of Case 2. It takes 𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|) time if |X|<k𝑋𝑘|X|<k.

If the procedure of Case 2 is called in a non-leaf node of the branching tree, then its 𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|) running time is dominated by the 𝒪​(|E|)𝒪𝐸\mathcal{O}(|E|) time that is required for further branching since |V|≤k​|E|𝑉𝑘𝐸|V|\leq k|E|. Hence, it suffices to bound (a) the total time complexity of calls to the algorithm for Case 2 in leaves that correspond to sets X𝑋X such that |X|<k𝑋𝑘|X|<k and (b) the total number of leaves that correspond to sets X𝑋X such that |X|=k𝑋𝑘|X|=k.

If k𝑘k is even, (a) is bounded by 𝒪​(|E|(k−2)/2​|V|)𝒪superscript𝐸𝑘22𝑉\mathcal{O}(|E|^{(k-2)/2}|V|) and (b) is bounded by 𝒪​(|E|k/2)𝒪superscript𝐸𝑘2\mathcal{O}(|E|^{k/2}). Hence, (b) dominates (a) and we have

𝒪​(|E|k/2)=𝒪​(|E|k/3​|E|k/6)=𝒪​(|E|k/3​|V|k/3).𝒪superscript𝐸𝑘2𝒪superscript𝐸𝑘3superscript𝐸𝑘6𝒪superscript𝐸𝑘3superscript𝑉𝑘3\mathcal{O}(|E|^{k/2})=\mathcal{O}(|E|^{k/3}|E|^{k/6})=\mathcal{O}(|E|^{k/3}|V|^{k/3}). (1)

If k𝑘k is odd, (a) is bounded by 𝒪​(|E|(k−1)/2​|V|)𝒪superscript𝐸𝑘12𝑉\mathcal{O}(|E|^{(k-1)/2}|V|) and (b) is bounded by 𝒪​(|E|(k−1)/2)𝒪superscript𝐸𝑘12\mathcal{O}(|E|^{(k-1)/2}), which is dominated by (a). By using (1) for k−3𝑘3k-3 we also have:

𝒪​(|E|(k−1)/2⋅|V|)=𝒪​(|E|(k−3)/2⋅|E|⋅|V|)=𝒪​((|E|⋅|V|)(k−3)/3⋅|E|⋅|V|)=𝒪​((|E|⋅|V|)k/3).𝒪⋅superscript𝐸𝑘12𝑉𝒪⋅superscript𝐸𝑘32𝐸𝑉𝒪⋅superscript⋅𝐸𝑉𝑘33𝐸𝑉𝒪superscript⋅𝐸𝑉𝑘3\mathcal{O}(|E|^{(k-1)/2}\cdot|V|)=\mathcal{O}(|E|^{(k-3)/2}\cdot|E|\cdot|V|)=\mathcal{O}((|E|\cdot|V|)^{(k-3)/3}\cdot|E|\cdot|V|)=\mathcal{O}((|E|\cdot|V|)^{k/3}).

We now consider the case that r​(H×K)=1𝑟𝐻𝐾1r(H\times K)=1. We use the algorithm for Case 2 above that works in 𝒪​(|V|)𝒪𝑉\mathcal{O}(|V|) time, which is 𝒪​(|V|⋅|E|)𝒪⋅𝑉𝐸\mathcal{O}(|V|\cdot|E|).

Lemmas 6.2-6.10 imply Theorem 6.1, which we employ iteratively to obtain the following.

Theorem 6.12.

PMDM can be solved in time 𝒪​(N+min⁡{Nk/3,ℓk})𝒪𝑁superscript𝑁𝑘3superscriptℓ𝑘\mathcal{O}(N+\min\{N^{k/3},\ell^{k}\}) and space 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N) if k=𝒪​(1)𝑘𝒪1k=\mathcal{O}(1).

Proof 6.13.

We apply the reduction of Lemma 6.2 and obtain a hypergraph with |V|=ℓ𝑉ℓ|V|=\ell and |E|=d𝐸𝑑|E|=d. Starting with k=1𝑘1k=1 and for growing values of k𝑘k, we solve Heaviest k𝑘k-Section until we obtain a solution of weight at least z𝑧z, employing either only Lemma 6.4, or Lemmas 6.4, 6.6, 6.8, 6.10 for k=1,2,3𝑘123k=1,2,3 and k≥4𝑘4k\geq 4, respectively. PMDM can thus be solved in 𝒪​(N+min⁡{Nk/3,ℓk})𝒪𝑁superscript𝑁𝑘3superscriptℓ𝑘\mathcal{O}(N+\min\{N^{k/3},\ell^{k}\}) time and linear space.

7 Exact Algorithms for a Bounded Number m𝑚m of Query Strings

Recall that masking a potential match (q1,q2)subscript𝑞1subscript𝑞2(q_{1},q_{2}) in record linkage can be performed by solving PMDM twice and superimposing the wildcards (see Section 1). In this section, we consider the following generalized version of PMDM to perform the masking simultaneously. The advantage of this approach is that it minimizes the final number of wildcards in q1subscript𝑞1q_{1} and q2subscript𝑞2q_{2}.

Multiple Pattern Masking for Dictionary Matching (MPMDM)
Input: A dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of d𝑑d strings, each of length ℓℓ\ell, a collection ℳℳ\mathcal{M} of m𝑚m strings, each of length ℓℓ\ell, and a positive integer z𝑧z. Output: A smallest set K⊆{1,…,ℓ}𝐾1…ℓK\subseteq\{1,\ldots,\ell\} such that, for every q𝑞q from ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K matches at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}.

Let N=d​ℓ𝑁𝑑ℓN=d\ell. We show the following theorem.

Theorem 7.1.

MPMDM can be solved in time 𝒪​(N+min⁡{Nk/3​zm−1,ℓk})𝒪𝑁superscript𝑁𝑘3superscript𝑧𝑚1superscriptℓ𝑘\mathcal{O}(N+\min\{N^{k/3}z^{m-1},\ell^{k}\}) if k=𝒪​(1)𝑘𝒪1k=\mathcal{O}(1) and m=𝒪​(1)𝑚𝒪1m=\mathcal{O}(1).

We use a generalization of Heaviest k𝑘k-Section in which the weights are m𝑚m-tuples that are added and compared component-wise and we aim to find a subset K𝐾K such that the weight of H×K𝐻𝐾H\times K is at least (z,…,z)𝑧…𝑧(z,\ldots,z). An analogue of Lemma 6.4 holds without any alterations, which accounts for the 𝒪​(N+ℓk)𝒪𝑁superscriptℓ𝑘\mathcal{O}(N+\ell^{k})-time algorithm. We adapt the proof of Lemma 6.10 as follows. The branching remains the same, but we have to tweak the final step, that is, what happens when we are in Case 2. For m=1𝑚1m=1 we could simply select a number of largest weights, but for m>1𝑚1m>1 multiple criteria need to be taken into consideration. All in all, the problem reduces to the following variation on the Multiple-Choice Knapsack problem [41].

κ𝜅\kappa Heaviest Vectors (κ𝜅\kappa-HV)
Input: A collection 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} of t𝑡t vectors from ℤ≥0msuperscriptsubscriptℤabsent0𝑚\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 0}^{m}, a vector x𝑥x from {0,…,z}msuperscript0…𝑧𝑚\{0,\ldots,z\}^{m}, for a positive integer z𝑧z, and an integer κ∈{0,…,t}𝜅0…𝑡\kappa\in\{0,\ldots,t\}. Output: Compute κ𝜅\kappa elements of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} (if they exist) such that if y𝑦y is their component-wise sum, y​[i]≥x​[i]𝑦delimited-[]𝑖𝑥delimited-[]𝑖y[i]\geq x[i] for all i∈{1,…,m}𝑖1…𝑚i\in\{1,\ldots,m\}.

The exact reduction from Case 2 is as follows: the set 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} contains weights of subsequent nodes v∈V∖X𝑣𝑉𝑋v\in V\setminus X (defined as the sums of weights of edges Y∪{v}∈E𝑌𝑣𝐸Y\cup\{v\}\in E for Y⊆X𝑌𝑋Y\subseteq X), so t≤|V|𝑡𝑉t\leq|V|, x𝑥x is (z,…,z)𝑧…𝑧(z,\ldots,z) minus the sum of weights of all edges e∈E𝑒𝐸e\in E such that e⊆X𝑒𝑋e\subseteq X, and κ=k−|X|𝜅𝑘𝑋\kappa=k-|X|.

The solution to κ𝜅\kappa-HV is a rather straightforward dynamic programming.

Lemma 7.2.

For κ,m=𝒪​(1)𝜅𝑚𝒪1\kappa,m=\mathcal{O}(1), κ𝜅\kappa-HV can be solved in time 𝒪​(t⋅zm−1)𝒪⋅𝑡superscript𝑧𝑚1\mathcal{O}(t\cdot z^{m-1}).

Proof 7.3.

We apply dynamic programming. Let 𝒯=v1,…,vt𝒯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑡\mathcal{T}=v_{1},\ldots,v_{t}. We compute an array A𝐴A of size 𝒪​(t​κ​zm−1)𝒪𝑡𝜅superscript𝑧𝑚1\mathcal{O}(t\kappa z^{m-1}) such that, for i∈{0,…,t}𝑖0…𝑡i\in\{0,\ldots,t\}, j∈{0,…,κ}𝑗0…𝜅j\in\{0,\ldots,\kappa\} and v∈{0,…,z}m−1𝑣superscript0…𝑧𝑚1v\in\{0,\ldots,z\}^{m-1},

A​[i,j,v]=max⁡{a:∃S⊆{v1,…,vi},|S|=j,∑u∈Su=(v,a)},𝐴𝑖𝑗𝑣:𝑎formulae-sequence𝑆subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑖formulae-sequence𝑆𝑗subscript𝑢𝑆𝑢𝑣𝑎A[i,j,v]=\max\{a\,:\,\exists S\subseteq\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{i}\},\,|S|=j,\,\sum_{u\in S}u=(v,a)\},

where (v,a)𝑣𝑎(v,a) denotes the operation of appending element a𝑎a to vector v𝑣v. From each state A​[i,j,v]𝐴𝑖𝑗𝑣A[i,j,v] we have two transitions, depending on whether vi+1subscript𝑣𝑖1v_{i+1} is taken to the subset or not. Each transition is computed in 𝒪​(m)=𝒪​(1)𝒪𝑚𝒪1\mathcal{O}(m)=\mathcal{O}(1) time. This gives time 𝒪​(t⋅zm−1)𝒪⋅𝑡superscript𝑧𝑚1\mathcal{O}(t\cdot z^{m-1}) in total.

The array is equipped with a standard technique to recover the set S𝑆S (parents of states). The final answer is computed by checking, for each vector v∈{0,…,z}m−1𝑣superscript0…𝑧𝑚1v\in\{0,\ldots,z\}^{m-1} such that v​[i]≥x​[i]𝑣delimited-[]𝑖𝑥delimited-[]𝑖v[i]\geq x[i], for all i=1,…,m−1𝑖1…𝑚1i=1,\ldots,m-1, if A​[t,κ,v]≥x​[m]𝐴𝑡𝜅𝑣𝑥delimited-[]𝑚A[t,\kappa,v]\geq x[m].

Overall, we pay an additional 𝒪​(zm−1)𝒪superscript𝑧𝑚1\mathcal{O}(z^{m-1}) factor in the complexity of handling of Case 2, which yields the complexity of Theorem 7.1.

8 Summary of Greedy Heuristic for PMDM and Experiments

We design a greedy heuristic for PMDM which, for a given constant τ≥1𝜏1\tau\geq 1, applies Theorem 6.1 iteratively, for some k≤τ𝑘𝜏k\leq\tau. In iteration i=1𝑖1i=1, we apply Theorem 6.1 for k=1,…,τ𝑘1…𝜏k=1,\ldots,\tau and check whether there are at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that can be matched when at most k𝑘k wildcards are substituted in the query string q𝑞q. If at least z𝑧z such strings exist, we return the minimum such k𝑘k and terminate. Clearly, by Theorem 6.12, the returned solution K1subscript𝐾1K_{1} is an optimal solution to PMDM. Otherwise, we proceed into the next iteration i=2𝑖2i=2. In this iteration, we construct string qK1=q⊗K1subscript𝑞subscript𝐾1tensor-product𝑞subscript𝐾1q_{K_{1}}=q\otimes K_{1} and apply Theorem 6.1, for k=1,…,τ𝑘1…𝜏k=1,\ldots,\tau, to qK1subscript𝑞subscript𝐾1q_{K_{1}}. This returns a solution K2subscript𝐾2K_{2} telling us whether there are at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that can be matched with qK2=qK1⊗K2subscript𝑞subscript𝐾2tensor-productsubscript𝑞subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2q_{K_{2}}=q_{K_{1}}\otimes K_{2}. If there exist such strings, we return K1∪K2subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1}\cup K_{2} and terminate. Otherwise, we proceed into iteration i=3𝑖3i=3, which is analogous to iteration i=2𝑖2i=2. The time complexity of the heuristic is 𝒪​((N+Nτ/3)​ℓ)𝒪𝑁superscript𝑁𝜏3ℓ\mathcal{O}((N+N^{\tau/3})\ell) and the space complexity is 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N). A complete description of the heuristic can be found in Appendix D.

An extensive experimental evaluation demonstrating the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed heuristic on real datasets used in record linkage, as well as on synthetic datasets, is presented in Appendix E. In the experiments that we have performed, the proposed heuristic: (I) produced nearly-optimal solutions for varying values of z𝑧z and ℓℓ\ell, even when applied with a small τ𝜏\tau; and (II) scaled as predicted by the complexity analysis, requiring fewer than 333 seconds for d=6⋅106𝑑⋅6superscript106d=6\cdot 10^{6} in all tested cases. These results suggest that our methods can inspire solutions in large-scale real-world systems, where no algorithms for PMDM exist.

Appendix A Other Related Work

  • •

    Dictionary Matching with k𝑘k-errors: A similar line of research to that of Partial Match has been conducted under the Hamming and edit distances, where, in this case, k𝑘k is the maximum allowed distance between the query string and a dictionary string [62, 17, 26, 13, 18, 14]. The structure of Dictionary Matching with k𝑘k-errors is very similar to Partial Match as each wildcard in the query string gives |Σ|Σ|\Sigma| possibilities for the corresponding symbol in the dictionary strings. On the other hand, in Partial Match the wildcard positions are fixed. Cohen-Addad, Feuilloley and Starikovskaya showed that in the pointer machine model one cannot avoid exponential dependency on k𝑘k either in the space or in the query time [25].

  • •

    Enumerating Motifs with k𝑘k-wildcards: Given an input string s𝑠s of length n𝑛n over an alphabet ΣΣ\Sigma and positive integers k𝑘k and z𝑧z, this problem asks to enumerate all motifs over Σ⊔{⋆}square-unionΣ⋆\Sigma\sqcup\{\star\} with up to k𝑘k wildcards that occur at least z𝑧z times in s𝑠s. As the size of the output is exponential in k𝑘k, the enumeration problem has such a lower bound. Several approaches exist for efficient motif enumeration, all aimed at reducing the impact of the output’s size: efficient indexing to minimise the output delay [31, 8]; exploiting a hierarchy of wildcards positions according to the number of occurrences [12]; or defining a subset of motifs of fixed-parameter tractable size (in k𝑘k or z𝑧z) that can generate all the others [51, 6, 54].

Appendix B On the Hardness of k𝑘k-Clique

Our reduction (Theorem 3.1) shows that solving k𝑘k-PMDM efficiently even for strings over a binary alphabet would imply a breakthrough for the k𝑘k-Clique problem for which it is known that, in general, no fixed-parameter tractable algorithm with respect to parameter k𝑘k exists unless the Exponential Time Hypothesis (ETH) fails [36]. That is, k𝑘k-Clique has no f​(k)​no​(k)𝑓𝑘superscript𝑛𝑜𝑘f(k)n^{o(k)} time algorithm, and is thus W[1]-complete (again, under the ETH hypothesis). On the upper bound side, k𝑘k-Clique can be trivially solved in 𝒪​(nk)𝒪superscript𝑛𝑘\mathcal{O}(n^{k}) time (enumerating all subsets of nodes of size k𝑘k), and this can be improved to 𝒪​(nω​k/3)𝒪superscript𝑛𝜔𝑘3\mathcal{O}(n^{\omega k/3}) time for k𝑘k divisible by 333 using square matrices multiplication (ω𝜔\omega is the exponent of square matrix multiplication). However, for general k≥3𝑘3k\geq 3 and any constant ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, the k𝑘k-Clique hypothesis states that there is no 𝒪​(n(ω/3−ϵ)​k)𝒪superscript𝑛𝜔3italic-ϵ𝑘\mathcal{O}(n^{(\omega/3-\epsilon)k})-time algorithm and no combinatorial 𝒪​(n(1−ϵ)​k)𝒪superscript𝑛1italic-ϵ𝑘\mathcal{O}(n^{(1-\epsilon)k})-time algorithm [20, 48, 61].

Given an undirected graph G𝐺G, an independent set is a subset of nodes of G𝐺G such that no two distinct nodes of the subset are adjacent. Let us note that the problem of computing a maximum clique in a graph G𝐺G, which is equivalent to that of computing the maximum independent set in the complement of G𝐺G, cannot be n1−ϵsuperscript𝑛1italic-ϵn^{1-\epsilon}-approximated in polynomial time, for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, unless P=NPPNP\text{P}=\text{NP} [32, 63].

Appendix C Material Omitted from the Approximation Algorithm for PMDM

Let us start by defining the Minimum Union (MU) problem [22].

Minimum Union (MU)
Input: A collection 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} of d𝑑d sets over a universe U𝑈U and a positive integer z≤d𝑧𝑑z\leq d. Output: A collection 𝒯⊆𝒮𝒯𝒮\mathcal{T}\subseteq\mathcal{S} with |𝒯|=z𝒯𝑧|\mathcal{T}|=z such that the size of ∪S∈𝒯Ssubscript𝑆𝒯𝑆\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S is minimized.

To illustrate the MU problem, consider an instance of it where U={1,2,3,4,5}𝑈12345U=\{1,2,3,4,5\}, 𝒮={{1},{1,2,3},{1,3,5},{3},{3,4,5},{4},{4,5},{5}}𝒮112313533454455\mathcal{S}=\{\{1\},\{1,2,3\},\{1,3,5\},\{3\},\{3,4,5\},\{4\},\{4,5\},\{5\}\}, with d=|𝒮|=8𝑑𝒮8d=|\mathcal{S}|=8, and z=4𝑧4z=4. Then 𝒯={{3},{3,4,5},{4},{4,5}}𝒯3345445\mathcal{T}=\{\{3\},\{3,4,5\},\{4\},\{4,5\}\} is a solution because |𝒯|=z=4𝒯𝑧4|\mathcal{T}|=z=4 and |∪S∈𝒯S|=3subscript𝑆𝒯𝑆3|\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S|=3 is minimum. The MU problem is NP-hard and the following approximation result is known.

Theorem C.1 ([22]).

For any constant ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, there is a polynomial-time 𝒪​(d1/4+ϵ)𝒪superscript𝑑14italic-ϵ\mathcal{O}(d^{1/4+\epsilon})-approximation algorithm for MU.

Theorem C.2.

PMDM can be reduced to MU in polynomial time.

Proof C.3.

We reduce the PMDM problem to MU in polynomial time as follows. Given any instance ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}} of PMDM, we construct an instance ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}} of MU in time 𝒪​(d​ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell) by performing the following steps:

  1. 1.

    The universe U𝑈U is set to {1,…,ℓ}1…ℓ\{1,\ldots,\ell\}.

  2. 2.

    We start with an empty collection 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. Then, for each string sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, we add member Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} to 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, where Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is the set of positions where string q𝑞q and string sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} have a mismatch. This can be done trivially in time 𝒪​(d​ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell) for all strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}.

  3. 3.

    Set the z𝑧z of the MU problem to the z𝑧z of the PMDM problem.

Thus, the total time 𝒪​(d​ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell) needed for Steps 1 to 3 above is clearly polynomial in the size of ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}. To conclude the proof, it remains to show that given a solution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}} we can obtain a solution K𝐾K to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}} in time polynomial in the size of ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}}, and that for each solution K𝐾K to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}, there exists a corresponding solution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}}.

(⇒⇒\Rightarrow) If 𝒯⊆𝒮𝒯𝒮\mathcal{T}\subseteq\mathcal{S} is a solution to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}}, then we can construct a string qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K that corresponds to 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} and is a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}. The construction of qKsubscript𝑞𝐾q_{K} can be performed in polynomial time by setting qK=qsubscript𝑞𝐾𝑞q_{K}=q and then substituting the positions of qKsubscript𝑞𝐾q_{K} corresponding to the elements of the sets of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} with wildcards. K𝐾K is a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}} because: (I) Since |𝒯|=z𝒯𝑧|\mathcal{T}|=z, string qKsubscript𝑞𝐾q_{K} matches at least z𝑧z strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. (II) Since |∪S∈𝒯S|subscript𝑆𝒯𝑆|\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S| is minimized, string qKsubscript𝑞𝐾q_{K} has the minimum number of wildcards.

(⇐⇐\Leftarrow) The output of PMDM is a set K𝐾K for matching at least z𝑧z strings but the output of MU is a collection 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} of size exactly z𝑧z, and so some work is required. If K𝐾K is a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}, we can obtain a solution 𝒯⊆𝒮𝒯𝒮\mathcal{T}\subseteq\mathcal{S} to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}} using a greedy approach. Let 𝒟′⊆𝒟superscript𝒟′𝒟\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{D} be the collection of strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that match qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K and 𝒮′⊆𝒮superscript𝒮′𝒮\mathcal{S}^{\prime}\subseteq\mathcal{S} be the collection of sets of mismatches corresponding to the strings in 𝒟′superscript𝒟′\mathcal{D}^{\prime}. To construct 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}, we select any z𝑧z sets S1′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1S^{\prime}_{1}, ……\ldots, Sz′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑧S^{\prime}_{z} from 𝒮′superscript𝒮′\mathcal{S}^{\prime}. Collection 𝒮′superscript𝒮′\mathcal{S}^{\prime} contains at least z𝑧z sets due to Step 1 above and the fact that K𝐾K is a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}. The correctness of this approach is implied by the fact that, if there is a 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} such that |𝒯|=z𝒯𝑧|\mathcal{T}|=z and ∪S∈𝒯S=Ksubscript𝑆𝒯𝑆𝐾\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S=K, then we would find it. Further, it is not possible that these z𝑧z sets do not cover K𝐾K. In that case, there would be z𝑧z sets in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} whose union is a proper subset K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} of K𝐾K, which is a contradiction as qK′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝐾′q_{K}^{\prime} would have fewer wildcards than qKsubscript𝑞𝐾q_{K} and K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} would be a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}. 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is a solution to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}} because: (I) |𝒯|=z𝒯𝑧|\mathcal{T}|=z by construction, and (II) |∪S∈𝒯S|subscript𝑆𝒯𝑆|\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S| is minimized because, by definition, the size of K𝐾K is minimized, which implies that |∪S∈𝒮′S|=|∪S∈𝒯S|subscript𝑆superscript𝒮′𝑆subscript𝑆𝒯𝑆|\cup_{S\in\mathcal{S}^{\prime}}S|=|\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S| is also minimized.

Proof of Theorem 4.1.

The reduction in Theorem C.2 implies that there is a polynomial-time approximation algorithm for PMDM. In particular, Theorem C.1 provides an approximation guarantee for MU that depends on the number of sets of the input 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. In Step 2 of the reduction of Theorem C.2, we construct one set for the MU instance per one string of the dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of the PMDM instance. Also, from the constructed solution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} to the MU instance, we obtain a solution K𝐾K to the PMDM instance by simply substituting the positions of q𝑞q corresponding to the elements of the sets of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} with wildcards. This construction implies the approximation result of Theorem 4.1 that depends on the size of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. We obtain Theorem 4.1.∎

Sanity Check.

Theorem 3.1 (reduction from k𝑘k-Clique to k𝑘k-PMDM) and Theorem 4.1 (approximation algorithm for PMDM) do not contradict the inapproximability results for the maximum clique problem (see Appendix B), since our reduction from k𝑘k-Clique to k𝑘k-PMDM cannot be adapted to a reduction from maximum clique to PMDM-Size.

Two-Way Reduction.

The reader can probably share the intuition that the opposite to the reduction of Theorem C.2 is easy to prove. We give this proof next for completeness.

Theorem C.4.

MU can be reduced to PMDM in polynomial time.

Proof C.5.

We reduce the MU problem to the PMDM problem in polynomial time as follows. Let ℓ=‖𝒮‖ℓnorm𝒮\ell=||\mathcal{S}|| denote the total number of elements in the d𝑑d members of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. Given any instance ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{{MU}}} of MU, we construct an instance ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}} of PMDM by performing the following steps:

  1. 1.

    Set the query string q𝑞q equal to the string aℓsuperscriptaℓ\texttt{a}^{\ell} of length ℓℓ\ell. This can be done in 𝒪​(ℓ)𝒪ℓ\mathcal{O}(\ell) time.

  2. 2.

    After sorting the union of all elements of members of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, we can assign to each element j𝑗j a unique rank rank​(j)∈{1,…,ℓ}rank𝑗1…ℓ\textsf{rank}(j)\in\{1,\ldots,\ell\}. For each set Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, construct a string si=aℓsubscript𝑠𝑖superscriptaℓs_{i}=\texttt{a}^{\ell}, set si​[rank​(j)]:=bassignsubscript𝑠𝑖delimited-[]rank𝑗bs_{i}[\textsf{rank}(j)]:=\texttt{b} if and only if j∈Si𝑗subscript𝑆𝑖j\in S_{i}, and add sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i} to dictionary 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. This can be done in 𝒪​(d​ℓ+ℓ​log⁡ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓℓℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell+\ell\log\ell) time.

  3. 3.

    Set the z𝑧z of the PMDM problem equal to the z𝑧z of the MU problem. This can be done in 𝒪​(1)𝒪1\mathcal{O}(1) time.

Thus, the total time 𝒪​(d​ℓ+ℓ​log⁡ℓ)𝒪𝑑ℓℓℓ\mathcal{O}(d\ell+\ell\log\ell) needed for Steps 1 to 3 above is clearly polynomial in the size of ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{MU}}. To conclude the proof, it remains to show that, given a solution K𝐾K to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}, we can obtain a solution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}} in time polynomial in the size of ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}, and that for each solution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}} there exists a corresponding solution K𝐾K in ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}.

(⇒⇒\Rightarrow) Let us first show how to obtain a solution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{{MU}}} from a solution string qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\text{{PMDM}}} in polynomial time in the size of ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}. K𝐾K corresponds to the minimized ∪S∈𝒯Ssubscript𝑆𝒯𝑆\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S of ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{MU}}. We now need to construct a solution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} by picking up exactly z𝑧z sets S1′,S2′,…,Sz′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1subscriptsuperscript𝑆′2…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑧S^{\prime}_{1},S^{\prime}_{2},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{z} of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} such that the rank of every element j𝑗j of Si′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖S^{\prime}_{i}, i∈[1,z]𝑖1𝑧i\in[1,z], is also an element of K𝐾K and every element of K𝐾K is covered by at least one rank​(j)rank𝑗\textsf{rank}(j) for some i,j𝑖𝑗i,j such that j∈Si′𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖j\in S^{\prime}_{i}. This can be done using a greedy approach. We first select all sets S1′,S2′,…,Sz′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1subscriptsuperscript𝑆′2…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′superscript𝑧′S^{\prime}_{1},S^{\prime}_{2},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{z^{\prime}} from 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} such that the rank of every element j𝑗j of Si′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖S^{\prime}_{i}, i∈[1,z′]𝑖1superscript𝑧′i\in[1,z^{\prime}], is also an element of K𝐾K. Note that by construction we have at least z𝑧z such sets (i.e. z′≥zsuperscript𝑧′𝑧z^{\prime}\geq z) because they correspond to at least z𝑧z strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that have b in a subset of the positions in K𝐾K. This selection can be done in 𝒪​(ℓ)𝒪ℓ\mathcal{O}(\ell) time using perfect hashing [29]. We now construct 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} by starting from the empty collection and adding to it any z𝑧z sets from S1′,S2′,…,Sz′′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1subscriptsuperscript𝑆′2…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′superscript𝑧′S^{\prime}_{1},S^{\prime}_{2},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{z^{\prime}}. The correctness of this approach is implied by the fact that if there is a 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} such that |𝒯|=z𝒯𝑧|\mathcal{T}|=z and ∪S∈𝒯S=Ksubscript𝑆𝒯𝑆𝐾\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S=K then we would find it. It is not possible that we would need more than these z𝑧z sets to cover K𝐾K. In that case, there would be z𝑧z sets that could cover a proper subset K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} of K𝐾K (i.e., there would be a qK′=q⊗K′superscriptsubscript𝑞𝐾′tensor-product𝑞superscript𝐾′q_{K}^{\prime}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K^{\prime} with fewer wildcards than qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K so that K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime} is also a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}) which is a contradiction. The whole process takes polynomial time in the size of ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}.

If K𝐾K is a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}} then 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is a solution to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\text{MU}} because: (I) The set K𝐾K corresponds to at least z𝑧z strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} by the definition of PMDM, which in turn by construction corresponds to z𝑧z sets of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} (Step 3 of the reduction and greedy selection of z𝑧z sets). (II) The size of K𝐾K is minimized by the definition of PPSM, which implies that the number of distinct occurrences (positions) of b in the strings of 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that are equal to the positions of ⋆⋆\star’s in qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K is also minimized. Since each such position corresponds to a unique rank in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} by construction (Step 3 of the reduction), it holds that |∪S∈𝒮S|subscript𝑆𝒮𝑆|\cup_{S\in\mathcal{S}}S| is minimized. From I and II, it holds that 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is a solution to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{MU}}.

(⇐⇐\Leftarrow) If 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is a solution to ℐMUsubscriptℐMU\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{MU}}, then K𝐾K is a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}} because: (I) Since |𝒯|=z𝒯𝑧|\mathcal{T}|=z, string qK=q⊗Ksubscript𝑞𝐾tensor-product𝑞𝐾q_{K}\!=\!q\!\otimes\!K matches at least z𝑧z strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. (II) Since |∪S∈𝒯S|subscript𝑆𝒯𝑆|\cup_{S\in\mathcal{T}}S| is minimized, qKsubscript𝑞𝐾q_{K} has the minimum number of ⋆⋆\star’s. From I and II, it holds that K𝐾K is a solution to ℐPMDMsubscriptℐPMDM\mathcal{I}_{\textsc{PMDM}}.

Appendix D A Greedy Heuristic for PMDM

For completeness, we provide a full description of the heuristic outlined in Section 8 below.

We design a heuristic called Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM which, for a given constant τ≥1𝜏1\tau\geq 1, applies iteratively Theorem 6.1, for k=1,…,τ𝑘1…𝜏k=1,\ldots,\tau. Intuitively, the larger the τ𝜏\tau the more effective but the slower Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM is. Specifically, in iteration i=1𝑖1i=1, we apply Theorem 6.1 for k=1,…,τ𝑘1…𝜏k=1,\ldots,\tau and check whether there are at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that can be matched when at most k𝑘k wildcards are substituted in the query string q𝑞q. If there are, we return the minimum such k𝑘k and terminate. Clearly, by Theorem 6.12, the returned solution K1subscript𝐾1K_{1} is an optimal solution to PMDM. Otherwise, we proceed into the next iteration i=2𝑖2i=2. In this iteration, we construct string qK1=q⊗K1subscript𝑞subscript𝐾1tensor-product𝑞subscript𝐾1q_{K_{1}}=q\otimes K_{1} and apply Theorem 6.1, for k=1,…,τ𝑘1…𝜏k=1,\ldots,\tau, to qK1subscript𝑞subscript𝐾1q_{K_{1}}. This returns a solution K2subscript𝐾2K_{2} telling us whether there are at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} that can be matched with qK2=qK1⊗K2subscript𝑞subscript𝐾2tensor-productsubscript𝑞subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2q_{K_{2}}=q_{K_{1}}\otimes K_{2}. If there are, we return K1∪K2subscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2K_{1}\cup K_{2}, which is now a (sub-optimal) solution to PMDM, and terminate. Otherwise, we proceed into iteration i=3𝑖3i=3, which is analogous to iteration i=2𝑖2i=2. Note that Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM always terminates with some (sub-optimal) solution K1∪K2∪⋯∪Kjsubscript𝐾1subscript𝐾2⋯subscript𝐾𝑗K_{1}\cup K_{2}\cup\cdots\cup K_{j}, for some j≤⌈ℓ/τ⌉𝑗ℓ𝜏j\leq\lceil\ell/\tau\rceil. Namely, in the worst case, it returns set {1,…,ℓ}1…ℓ\{1,\ldots,\ell\} after ⌈ℓ/τ⌉ℓ𝜏\lceil\ell/\tau\rceil iterations and q{1,…,ℓ}subscript𝑞1…ℓq_{\{1,\ldots,\ell\}} matches all strings in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. The reason why Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM does not guarantee finding an optimal solution to PMDM is that at iteration i𝑖i we fix the positions of wildcards based on solution K1∪⋯∪Ki−1subscript𝐾1⋯subscript𝐾𝑖1K_{1}\cup\cdots\cup K_{i-1}. Since τ=𝒪​(1)𝜏𝒪1\tau=\mathcal{O}(1), the time complexity of Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM is 𝒪​((N+Nτ/3)​ℓ)𝒪𝑁superscript𝑁𝜏3ℓ\mathcal{O}((N+N^{\tau/3})\ell): each iteration takes time 𝒪​(N+Nτ/3)𝒪𝑁superscript𝑁𝜏3\mathcal{O}(N+N^{\tau/3}) by Theorem 6.1, and then there are no more than ⌈ℓ/τ⌉=𝒪​(ℓ)ℓ𝜏𝒪ℓ\lceil\ell/\tau\rceil=\mathcal{O}(\ell) iterations. The space complexity of Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM is 𝒪​(N)𝒪𝑁\mathcal{O}(N). The hypergraph H=(V,E)𝐻𝑉𝐸H=(V,E) used in the implementation of Theorem 6.1 has edges of size up to k𝑘k. If every string in 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} has more than k𝑘k mismatches with q𝑞q, all edges in H𝐻H have size larger than k𝑘k. In this case, we preprocess H𝐻H, removing selected nodes and edges from it, so that it has at least one edge of size up to k𝑘k and then apply Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM.

Hypergraph Preprocessing.

Let us now complete the algorithm by describing the hypergraph preprocessing. We want to ensure that hypergraph H=(V,E)𝐻𝑉𝐸H=(V,E) has at least one edge of size up to k𝑘k so that Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM can be applied. To this end, if there is no edge of size up to k𝑘k at some iteration, we add some nodes into the partial solution with the following heuristic. We assign a score s​(u)𝑠𝑢s(u) to each node u𝑢u in V𝑉V using the function:

s​(u)=|Eu|⋅∑e∈Euw​(e)∑e∈Eu|e|,𝑠𝑢⋅subscript𝐸𝑢subscript𝑒subscript𝐸𝑢𝑤𝑒subscript𝑒subscript𝐸𝑢𝑒s(u)=|E_{u}|\cdot\frac{\sum_{e\in E_{u}}w(e)}{\sum_{e\in E_{u}}|e|},

where Eu={e∈E:u∈e}subscript𝐸𝑢conditional-set𝑒𝐸𝑢𝑒E_{u}=\{e\in E:u\in e\} and w​(e)𝑤𝑒w(e) is the edge weight. Then, we add the node with maximum score from H𝐻H (breaking ties arbitrarily) into the partial solution and update the edges accordingly. This process is repeated until there is at least one edge of size up to k𝑘k; it takes 𝒪​(d​ℓ2)𝒪𝑑superscriptℓ2\mathcal{O}(d\ell^{2}) time. After that, we add the removed nodes into the current solution Kksubscript𝐾𝑘K_{k} and use the resultant hypergraph when we apply Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM.

The intuition behind the above process is to add nodes which appear in many short edges (so that we mask few positions) with large weight (so that the masked positions greatly increase the number of matched strings). We have also tried a different scoring function s′​(u)=∑e∈Euw​(e)|e|superscript𝑠′𝑢subscript𝑒subscript𝐸𝑢𝑤𝑒𝑒s^{\prime}(u)=\sum_{e\in E_{u}}\frac{w(e)}{|e|} instead of s​(u)𝑠𝑢s(u), but the results were worse in terms of AvgRE and AvgSS, so we have omitted them.

Appendix E Experimental Evaluation

Methods.

We compared the performance of our heuristic Greedy τ𝜏\tau-PMDM (GR τ𝜏\tau), for the values τ∈[3,5]𝜏35\tau\in[3,5], for which its time complexity is subquadratic in N𝑁N, to the following two algorithms:

  • •

    Baseline (BA). In iteration i𝑖i, BA adds a node of hypergraph H𝐻H into K𝐾K and updates H𝐻H according to the preprocessing described in Appendix D. If at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} match the query string q𝑞q after the positions in q𝑞q corresponding to K𝐾K are replaced with wildcards, BA returns K𝐾K and terminates; otherwise, it proceeds into iteration i+1𝑖1i+1. Note that BA generally constructs a suboptimal solution K𝐾K to PMDM and takes 𝒪​(d​ℓ2)𝒪𝑑superscriptℓ2\mathcal{O}(d\ell^{2}) time.

  • •

    Bruteforce (BF). In iteration i𝑖i, BF applies Lemma 6.4 in the process of obtaining an optimal solution K𝐾K of size i=k𝑖𝑘i=k to PMDM. In particular, it checks whether at least z𝑧z strings from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} match the query string q𝑞q, after the i𝑖i positions in q𝑞q corresponding to K𝐾K are replaced with wildcards. If the check succeeds, BF returns K𝐾K and terminates; otherwise, it proceeds into iteration i+1𝑖1i+1. BF takes 𝒪​(k​(2​ℓ)k+d​k)𝒪𝑘superscript2ℓ𝑘𝑑𝑘\mathcal{O}(k(2\ell)^{k}+dk) time (see Lemma 6.4).

We used our own baseline in the evaluation, since there are no existing algorithms for addressing PMDM, as mentioned in Introduction. We have implemented all of the above algorithms in C++. Our implementations can be made available upon request.

Datasets.

We used the North Carolina Voter Registration database [3] (NCVR); a standard benchmark dataset for record linkage [24, 28, 38, 59]. NCVR is a collection of 7,736,911 records with attributes such as Forename, Surname, City, County, and Gender. We generated 4 subcollections of NCVR: (I) FS is comprised of all 952,864 records having Forename and Surname of total length ℓ=15ℓ15\ell=15; (II) FCi is comprised of all 342,472 records having Forename and City of total length ℓ=15ℓ15\ell=15; (III) FCiCo is comprised of all 342,472 records having Forename, City, and County of total length ℓ=30ℓ30\ell=30; and (IV) FSCiCo is comprised of all 8,238 records having Forename, Surname, City and County of total length ℓ=45ℓ45\ell=45.

We also generated a synthetic dataset, referred to as SYN, using the IBM Synthetic Data Generator [1], a standard tool for generating sequential datasets [27, 34]. SYN contains a collection of 6⋅106⋅6superscript1066\cdot 10^{6} records, each of length ℓ=50ℓ50\ell=50, over an alphabet of size |Σ|=10Σ10|\Sigma|=10. We also used subcollections of SYN comprised of x⋅106⋅𝑥superscript106x\cdot 10^{6} records of length y𝑦y, each referred to as SYNx.y.

Comparison Measures.

We evaluated the effectiveness of the algorithms using: (I) An Average Relative Error (AvgRE) measure, computed as avgki−ki∗ki∗i∈[1,1000]subscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑖𝑖11000{}_{i\in[1,1000]}\frac{k_{i}-k^{*}_{i}}{k^{*}_{i}}, where ki∗superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i}^{*} is the size of the optimal solution, produced by BF, and kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} is the size of the solution produced by one of the other tested algorithms. Both ki∗superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i}^{*} and kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} are obtained by using, as query qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}, a record of the input dictionary selected uniformly at random. (II) An Average Solution Size (AvgSS) measure computed as avgki∗i∈[1,1000]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑘𝑖𝑖11000{}_{i\in[1,1000]}k^{*}_{i} for BF and avgkii∈[1,1000]subscriptsubscript𝑘𝑖𝑖11000{}_{i\in[1,1000]}k_{i} for any other algorithm. We evaluated efficiency by reporting avgtii∈[1,1000]subscriptsubscript𝑡𝑖𝑖11000{}_{i\in[1,1000]}t_{i}, where tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} is the elapsed time of a tested algorithm to obtain a solution for query qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} over the input dictionary.

Execution Environment.

We used a PC with Intel Xeon E5-2640@2.66GHz and 160GB RAM running GNU/Linux; and compiler gcc v.7.3.1 at optimization level -O3.

Effectiveness.

Figures 3 and 4(a) show that GR produced nearly-optimal solutions, significantly outperforming BA. In Figure 3(a), the solutions of GR 3 were no more than 9%percent99\% worse than the optimal, while those of BA were up to 95%percent9595\% worse. In Figure 4(a), the average solution size of BF was 5.45.45.4 vs. 5.95.95.9 and 999, for the solution size of GR 3 and BA, respectively.

In Figures 4(b) and 4(c), we examined the effectiveness of GR for larger ℓℓ\ell values. Figure 4(b) shows that the solution size of GR 3 was at least 31%percent3131\% and up to 60%percent6060\% smaller than that of BA on average, while Figure 4(c) shows that the solution of GR 3 was comparable to that of GR 4 and 5. We omit the results for BF from Figures 4(b) and 4(c) and those for BA from Figure 4(c), as these algorithms did not produce results for all queries within 48 hours, for any z𝑧z. This is because, unlike GR, BF does not scale well with ℓℓ\ell and BA does not scale well with the solution size, as we will explain later.

Note that increasing τ𝜏\tau generally increases the effectiveness of GR as it computes more positions of wildcards per iteration. However, even with τ=3𝜏3\tau=3, it remains competitive to BF.

Efficiency.

Having shown that GR produced nearly-optimal solutions, we now show that it is comparable in terms of efficiency or faster than BA for synthetic data. (BF was at least two orders of magnitude slower than the other methods on average and thus we omit its results.) The results for NCVR were qualitatively similar (omitted). Figure 5(a) shows that GR spent, on average, the same time for a query as BA did. However, it took significantly (up to 363636 times) less time than BA for queries with large solution size k𝑘k. This can be seen from Figure 5(b), which shows the time each query with solution size k𝑘k took; the results for GR 3 and 4 were similar and thus omitted. The reason is that BA updates the hypergraph every time a node is added into the solution, which is computationally expensive when k𝑘k is large. Figures 5(c) and 5(d) show that all algorithms scaled sublinearly with d𝑑d and with z𝑧z, respectively. The increase with d𝑑d is explained by the time complexity of the methods. The slight increase with z𝑧z is because k𝑘k gets larger, on average, as z𝑧z increases. GR 3 and 4 performed similarly to each other, being faster than GR 5 in all experiments as expected: increasing τ𝜏\tau from 3 or 4 to 5 trades-off effectiveness for efficiency.

Figures 6(a), 6(b), and 6(c) show the average solution size in the experiments of Figure 5(a), 5(c), and 5(d), respectively. Observe that the results are analogous to those obtained using the NCVR datasets: GR outperforms BA significantly. Also, observe in Figure 6(c) that the solution size of each tested algorithm gets larger, on average, as z𝑧z increases.
